facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 350 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.350 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 6, 1956, of the Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 6, 1956, of the Calcutta High Court on a numberice of motion in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

facts.text: The order was on a notice of motion in Appeal No. 152 of 1955 before Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Calcutta High Court on a numberice of motion in Appeal No. 152 of 1955. C. Chatterjee and P. K. Mukherjee, for the appellant.

facts.text: Sudhir Kumar Mitter was the owner of two houses, No. 86/1, Cornwallis Street and No. 7-C, Kirti Mitter Lane, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent, Sudhir Kumar Mitter, was the owner of two houses, No. 86/1, Cornwallis Street and No. 7-C, Kirti Mitter Lane, Calcutta. On May 19, 1934,

facts.text: On May 19, 1934, Sudhir Kumar Mitter executed a mortgage for Rs. 3,000 over the said houses in favour of Sm. Nirmala Sundari Dassi.

anchor.surface_text: On May 19, 1934, he executed a mortgage for Rs. 3,000 over the said houses in favour of the first respondent, Sm. Nirmala Sundari Dassi. She instituted Suit No. 158 of 1935

facts.text: Sm. Nirmala Sundari Dassi instituted Suit No. 158 of 1935 on this mortgage and obtained a preliminary decree on March 8, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: She instituted Suit No. 158 of 1935 on this mortgage, and obtained a pre- liminary decree on March 8, 1935. The matter then came before the Registrar for taking of accounts,

facts.text: Registrar's report dated July 23, 1935 found Rs. 3,914-6-6 due, and final decree passed on April 20, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The matter then came before the Registrar for taking of accounts, and by his report dated July 23, 1935 he found that a sum 1289 of Rs. 3,914-6-6 was due to her, and on that, a final decree was passed on April 20, 1936.

facts.text: First respondent took no steps to have the decree drawn up for nearly 18 years.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent who had acted with such alacrity and speed in putting her mortgage in suit and obtaining a decree, took numbersteps whatsoever to have the decree drawn up, for nearly 18 years.

facts.text: On May 12, 1952, second respondent sold both houses to the appellant for Rs. 60,000.

anchor.surface_text: On May 12, 1952, the second respondent sold both the houses to the appellant herein for a sum of Rs. 60,000 which was, it is stated, utilised largely for discharging prior mortgages

facts.text: The deed of sale recites that the properties were sold free of all encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: The deed of sale recites that the properties were sold free of all encumbrances. The first respondent who had so far taken numbersteps to have the decree drawn up

facts.text: On February 17, 1954, first respondent obtained ex parte order under r.27 to draw up and complete the decree.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent who had so far taken numbersteps to have the decree drawn up number bestirred herself, and on February 17, 1954 obtained an ex parte order under r. 27 aforesaid, granting her leave to draw up and companylete the decree.

facts.text: On April 29, 1954, first respondent filed the final decree and commenced proceedings for sale.

anchor.surface_text: That having been done pursuant to the order, she filed on April 29, 1954 the final decree, and companymenced proceedings for sale of the mortgaged properties.

facts.text: Second respondent objected that execution of the decree was barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to know of this, the second respondent appeared before the Registrar, and raised the objection that the execution of the decree was barred by limitation.

facts.text: P.B. Mukharji J. held that execution was not barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The matter then came before P. B. Mukharji J. and after hearing 1290 companynsel for both the respondents, he held that the execution of the decree was number barred. Vide judgment reported in Nirmala Sundari v. Sudhir Kumar  1 .

facts.text: Second respondent preferred Appeal No. 152 of 1955 against the judgment, which is still pending.

anchor.surface_text: Against this judgment, the second respondent preferred Appeal No. 152 of 1955, and that is still pending.

facts.text: On July 25, 1956, appellant applied to be brought on record as appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: We number companye to the application, out of which the present appeal arises. On July 25, 1956 the appellant applied to be brought on record as appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

facts.text: Appellant alleged purchase on May 12, 1952 free of encumbrances, execution barred, second respondent acted for her benefit but now collusive.

anchor.surface_text: The allegations in support of the petition were that she had purchased the properties from the second respondent on May 12, 1952 free of all encumbrances, that the execution proceedings started by the first respondent were number maintainable as the decree had become time-barred, that the second respondent, Sudhir Kumar Mitter, had been companyducting proceedings in opposition to the execution sale only at her instance and for her benefit,

facts.text: Prayer was to substitute in place of second respondent or as additional appellant.

anchor.surface_text: that therefore it was necessary that she should be allowed to companye on record as appellant so that she might protect her interests. The prayer in the petition was that she be substituted in the place of the second respondent or in the alternative, be brought on record as additional appellant.

facts.text: Respondents opposed, stated settlement at Rs. 17,670, fair, bona fide, binding on appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The application was strenuously opposed by both the respondents. They stated that they had entered into an arrangement settling the amount due to the first respondent at Rs. 17,670, that that settlement was fair and bona fide and binding on the appellant,

facts.text: Chakravarti C.J. and Lahiri J. dismissed the application by order dated August 6, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This application was heard by Chakravarti C. J. and Lahiri J. and by their order dated August 6, 1956, they dismissed it.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter obtained special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution, and that is how the appeal companyes before us.

facts.text: Respondents settled amount due at Rs. 17,670.

anchor.surface_text: Both the respondents claim that they have settled it at Rs. 17,670.

facts.text: Appellant contends amount under decree not exceed Rs. 6,000.

anchor.surface_text: But it is stated for the appellant that under the decree which is sought to be executed the amount recoverable for principal and interest will number exceed Rs. 6,000.

facts.text: Affidavit of Sanjit Kumar Ghose dated December 20, 1956 for first respondent gives particulars of Rs. 17,670: Rs. 7,200 interest up to March 8, 1956 at contract rate.

anchor.surface_text: In the affidavit of Sanjit Kumar Ghose dated December 20, 1956, filed on behalf of the first respondent, particulars are given as to how the sum of Rs. 17,670 was made up. It will be seen therefrom that a sum of Rs. 7,200 is claimed for interest up to March 8, 1956, calculating it number at the rate provided in the final decree but at the companytract rate.

facts.text: Rs. 5,000 included as costs in suits other than Suit No. 158 of 1935.

anchor.surface_text: Then a sum of Rs. 5,000 is included as for companyts incurred by the mortgagee in suits other than I.L.R. 1952 Mad. 622. 1294 Suit No. 158 of 1935 and in proceedings companynected therewith.

facts.text: Rs. 1,750 agreed for costs in sale reference, proceedings before P.B. Mukharji J. and Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: A sum of Rs. 1,750 is agreed to be paid for companyts in the sale reference, in the proceedings before P. B. Mukharji J. and in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.
under Art. 136 of the Constitution, and that is how the appeal comes before us.

issues.text: Whether the appellant's application to be brought on record as appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955 is maintainable under Order 22 Rule 10 of the Civil Procedure Code, given that the transfer was prior to the appeal but during pendency of the suit until decree drawn up

anchor.surface_text: It is contended on behalf of the appellant that her application is maintainable under 0. 22, r. 10 of the Civil Procedure Code, because Suit No. 158 of 1935 must be considered to have been pending until the decree therein was drawn up which was in 1954, and the transfer in her favour had been made prior thereto on May 12, 1952. The decision in Lakshan Chunder Dey v. Sm. Nikunjamani Dassi 1 is relied on, in support of this position. But it is contended for the first respondent that even if Suit No. 158 of 1935 is considered as pending when the transfer in favour of the appellant was made, that would not affect the result as no application had been made by her to be brought on record in the original court during the pendency of the suit. Nor could the application made to the appellate Court be sustained under 0. 22, r. 10, as the transfer in favour of the appellant was made prior to the filing of that appeal and not during its pendency. This contention appears to be well-founded

issues.text: Whether the appellant's application falls within Section 146 of the Civil Procedure Code entitling her to be brought on record as a person claiming under the second respondent

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the application filed by the appellant falls within s. 146 of the Civil Procedure Code, and she is entitled to be brought on record under that section. Section 146 provides that save as otherwise provided by the Code, any proceeding which can be taken by a person may also be taken by any person claiming under him. It has been held in Sitharamaswami v. Lakshmi Narasimha 2 that an appeal is a proceeding for the purpose of this section, and that further the expression claiming under is wide enough to include cases of devolution and assignment mentioned in 0. 22, r. 10.

issues.text: Whether Section 146 CPC allows a transferee to continue an appeal already filed by the transferor, or only to initiate new proceedings

anchor.surface_text: This decision was quoted with approval by this Court in Jugalkishore Saraf v. Raw Cotton Co., Ltd. 1 , wherein it was hold that a transferee of a debt on which a suit was pending was entitled to execute the decree which was subsequently passed therein, under s. 146 of the Civil Procedure Code as a person claiming under the decree-holder, even though an application for execution by him would not lie under 0. 21, r. 16, and it was further observed that the words save as otherwise provided only barred proceedings, which would be obnoxious to some provision of the Code. It would follow from the above authorities that whoever is entitled to be but has not been brought on record under 0. 22, r. 10 in a pending suit or proceeding would be entitled to prefer an appeal against the decree or order passed therein if his assignor could have filed such an appeal, there being no prohibition against it in the Code, and that accordingly the appellant as an assignee of the second respondent of the mortgaged properties would have been entitled to prefer an appeal against the judgment of P. B. Mukharji J. It is next contended that s. 146 authorises only the initiation of any proceeding, and that though it would have been competent to the appellant to have preferred an appeal against the judoment of P. B. Mukharji J. she not having done so was not entitled to be brought on record as an appellant to continue the appeal preferred by the second respondent.

holdings.text: The appellant's application to be brought on record is not maintainable under Order 22 Rule 10 CPC because no application was made in the original court and the transfer was prior to the filing of the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: But it is contended for the first respondent that even if Suit No. 158 of 1935 is considered as pending when the transfer in favour of the appellant was made, that would not affect the result as no application had been made by her to be brought on record in the original court during the pendency of the suit. This contention appears to be well-founded

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming suit pending until decree drawn up, no trial court application made; transfer predates appeal so O22 r10 inapplicable at appellate stage.

holdings.text: The appellant's application falls within Section 146 CPC as a person claiming under the second respondent and she is entitled to be brought on record under that section; appeal is a 'proceeding' and 'claiming under' includes assignment.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the application filed by the appellant falls within s. 146 of the Civil Procedure Code, and she is entitled to be brought on record under that section. Section 146 provides that save as otherwise provided by the Code, any proceeding which can be taken by a person may also be taken by any person claiming under him. It has been held in Sitharamaswami v. Lakshmi Narasimha 2 that an appeal is a proceeding for the purpose of this section, and that further the expression claiming under is wide enough to include cases of devolution and assignment mentioned in 0. 22, r. 10.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of S146 text; supported by precedents holding appeals as proceedings and broad 'claiming under'.

holdings.text: Section 146 CPC permits a transferee to continue an appeal already filed by the transferor, not just initiate new proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was quoted with approval by this Court in Jugalkishore Saraf v. Raw Cotton Co., Ltd. 1 , wherein it was hold that a transferee of a debt on which a suit was pending was entitled to execute the decree which was subsequently passed therein, under s. 146 of the Civil Procedure Code as a person claiming under the decree-holder, even though an application for execution by him would not lie under 0. 21, r. 16, and it was further observed that the words save as otherwise provided only barred proceedings, which would be obnoxious to some provision of the Code. It would follow from the above authorities that whoever is entitled to be but has not been brought on record under 0. 22, r. 10 in a pending suit or proceeding would be entitled to prefer an appeal against the decree or order passed therein if his assignor could have filed such an appeal, there being no prohibition against it in the Code, and that accordingly the appellant as an assignee of the second respondent of the mortgaged properties would have been entitled to prefer an appeal against the judgment of P. B. Mukharji J. It is next contended that s. 146 authorises only the initiation of any proceeding, and that though it would have been competent to the appellant to have preferred an appeal against the judoment of P. B. Mukharji J. she not having done so was not entitled to be brought on record as an appellant to continue the appeal preferred by the second respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects narrow construction; S146 beneficent provision for devolution/assignment to be construed liberally; precedents allow continuation in execution, extends to appeals; no Code prohibition.

holdings.text: On merits, the appellant should be brought on record as there are substantial questions on limitation, amount due under decree (Rs6000 vs Rs17670 including disputed interest/costs), and settlement not binding on her; as purchaser pendente lite bound by proceedings but entitled to protect interests.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Purchased for Rs60k free of encumbrance; execution after 18yrs delay; disputed limitation (substantial per lower court); amount inflated by contract interest not decree rate, extraneous costs Rs5k, disputed settlement; natural justice requires hearing purchaser pendente lite who is vitally interested.

anchor.surface_text: But it is contended for the first respondent that even if Suit No. 158 of 1935 is considered as pending when the transfer in favour of the appellant was made, that would not affect the result as no application had been made by her to be brought on record in the original court during the pendency of the suit. Nor could the application made to the appellate Court be sustained under 0. 22, r. 10, as the transfer in favour of the appellant was made prior to the filing of that appeal and not during its pendency. This contention appears to be well-founded
We accordingly set aside the order of the Court below dated August 6, 1956 and direct that the appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 o

edges.explanation: Entitlement to be brought on record under Section 146 (h2) supports merits determination in h4

anchor.surface_text: n, but a reading of his judgment shows-and that is what he himself observes-that there are substantial questions of law calling for decision. Even apa

edges.explanation: Holding h2 directly resolves issue i2 by affirming the application falls within Section 146 CPC

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the application filed by the appellant falls within s. 146 of the Civil Procedure Code, and she is entitled to be brought on record under that section. Section 146 provides that save as otherwise provided by the Code, any proceeding which can be taken by a person may also be taken by any person claiming under him. It has been held in Sitharamaswami v. Lakshmi Narasimha 2 that an appeal is a proceeding for the purpose of this section, and that further the expression claiming under is wide enough to include cases of devolution and assignment mentioned in 0. 22, r. 10.
We accordingly set aside the order of the Court below dated August 6, 1956 and direct that the appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 o

edges.explanation: h3's holding that Section 146 allows continuing an existing appeal supports h2's holding on bringing appellant on record in the appeal

anchor.surface_text: first respondent, particulars are given as to how the sum of Rs. 17,670 was made up. It will be seen therefrom that a sum of Rs. 7,200 is claimed for

edges.explanation: Holding h3 directly answers issue i3 affirmatively regarding continuation of appeals under Section 146 CPC

anchor.surface_text: This decision was quoted with approval by this Court in Jugalkishore Saraf v. Raw Cotton Co., Ltd. 1 , wherein it was hold that a transferee of a debt on which a suit was pending was entitled to execute the decree which was subsequently passed therein, under s. 146 of the Civil Procedure Code as a person claiming under the decree-holder, even though an application for execution by him would not lie under 0. 21, r. 16, and it was further observed that the words save as otherwise provided only barred proceedings, which would be obnoxious to some provision of the Code. It would follow from the above authorities that whoever is entitled to be but has not been brought on record under 0. 22, r. 10 in a pending suit or proceeding would be entitled to prefer an appeal against the decree or order passed therein if his assignor could have filed such an appeal, there being no prohibition against it in the Code, and that accordingly the appellant as an assignee of the second respondent of the mortgaged properties would have been entitled to prefer an appeal against the judgment of P. B. Mukharji J. It is next contended that s. 146 authorises only the initiation of any proceeding, and that though it would have been competent to the appellant to have preferred an appeal against the judoment of P. B. Mukharji J. she not having done so was not entitled to be brought on record as an appellant to continue the appeal preferred by the second respondent.
We accordingly set aside the order of the Court below dated August 6, 1956 and direct that the appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 o
